results.title: Excalibur
results.creator_credit: John Boorman and Orion Pictures Corporation
results.brief_description: The story of King Arthur and the Knights of the Round Table has inspired people for centuries. Arthur (Nigel Terry) has removed the magic sword Excalibur from the sacred stone and sets out to reunite the land as its King. Helen Mirren is the beautiful but sinister Morganna, Arthur’s half-sister, and Nicol Williamson is Merlin. This timeless tale includes the search for the Holy Grail and the tragic love of Guinevere and Lancelot. Cast also includes Nicholas Clay, Cherie Lunghi, Paul Geoffrey.

results.title: The Secret garden (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Fred M Wilcox, Clarence Brown and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: A delightful dramatisation based on the well-known children’s book of the same name. A young girl comes to live in a run down Victorian estate and finds an abandoned garden which she cares for. She befriends the young crippled son of the house - with amazing results. Starring Margaret O’Brien and Dean Stcokwell.

results.title: The Greatest show on Earth
results.creator_credit: Cecil B. DeMille and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Cecil B. DeMille blended drama with spectacle, using the Ringling Bros. Barnum & Bailey Circus as a backdrop. The film is a behind-the- scenes look at the triumphs and conflicts of circus performers. The magic and thrill of life under the Big Top is stunningly recreated. The all-star cast includes Betty Hutton, Cornel Wilde, Charlton Heston, Dorothy Lamour and James Stewart as “Buttons the Clown”. Filled with romance, intrigue and high-flying acrobatics, “The Greatest Show on Earth” is exactly that.

results.title: Allegro non troppo
results.brief_description: A parody of the Disney film “Fantasia”, “Allegro non troppo” features the highly creative work of talented Italian animator Bruno Bozzetto. It transcends the genre of parody to become a beautiful film in its own right. There are six animated sequences set to classical music, linked together by live-action scenes subtitled in English. The all-female orchestra is composed of old women and directed by a mad conductor (Maurizio Nichetti). This version features ten minutes of previously unreleased music and includes the music of Debussy, Dvorak, Ravel, Sibelius, Vivaldi and Stravinsky.

results.title: Ordinary people
results.creator_credit: Robert Redford, Ronald L Schwary, Paramount Pictures and Wildwood Enterprises
results.brief_description: Ordinary people places the “modern middle-class American family” under a microscope. Mary Tyler Moore and Donald Sutherland are the ideal couple, until their lives are shattered by the tragic death of their oldest son in a boating accident. Their perfect world is turned upside down as their youngest son, (Timothy Hutton) attempts suicide in order to ease the burden of guilt. An empathetic psychiatrist (Judd Hirsch), provides the teenager with a lifeline on the road to recovery. Mary Tyler Moore’s performance as the cold and aloof mother is outstanding. Donald Sutherland as the weak, ineffectual but loving father, grapples to come to terms with the tensions in his family relationships to which he was oblivious. Compelling and moving, “Ordinary people” is an outstanding directorial debut by Robert Redford. Based on novel by Judith Guest.

results.title: Bad boy Bubby
results.creator_credit: Rolf De Heer, Giorgio Draskovic, Domenico Procacci, Bubby Pty Ltd (Adelaide) and Fandango
results.brief_description: Bubby (Nicholas Hope in a knockout performance) has spent the first thirty-five years of his life locked in a filthy room by a mother who systematically emotionally and sexually abuses him. His first encounter with his father ends in a violent confrontation which results in Bubby breaking through to the outside world. Alone and frightened, a child in an adult man’s body, he begins his first tentative steps into humanity. This strange, absorbing and distressing film is a stunning investigation into the alienation lacerating urban contemporary Australia. Watching the world through Bubby’s eyes challenges the viewer to re-examine our conventional ideas of what is “normal” and what is “strange”. Family, sexual politics, work, art, and adulthood are questioned by Bubby’s progress through the modern world. Winner of four AFI awards and the Grand Jury Special Prize at the Venice Film Festival.

results.title: The Phantom of the opera
results.creator_credit: Arthur Lubin, George Waggner and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Gaston Leroux’s classic horror tale stars Claude Rains as the immortal phantom who haunts the Paris Opera. As a crazed composer, he is haunted by the beautiful soprano of the company, (Susanna Foster), and is determined to revenge himself upon those who have stolen his music. Nelson Eddy plays the heroic young baritone who tracks down the disfigured madman who has begun to murder those who resist his demands. The lavish colour production moves to a terrifying climax as the phantom is chased through the catacombs of Paris.

results.title: Forbidden planet
results.creator_credit: Fred Wilcox, Nicholas Nayfack and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: The year is 2257AD and the distant planet Altair-IV has three lone inhabitants: Professor Morbius (Walter Pidgeon), a fugitive super-scientist who has created a world of futuristic marvels; his daughter Altaira (Ann Francis), a bewitching innocent who has lived her entire life on the planet: and their servant, Robby the Robot. Then Commander Adams (Leslie Nielsen) arrives, and what ensues is a spine-chilling adventure with a hint of romance. “Forbidden planet” became a cult classic.

results.title: Little women
results.brief_description: Louisa May Alcott’s popular novel is brought vividly to life in this second screen adaption of “Little Women.” The March sisters are Jo (June Allyson), Beth (Janet Leigh), Amy (a blonde Elizabeth Taylor) and Meg (child-star Margaret O’Brien). Their father has left for the Civil War, leaving the girls under the watchful eye of their mother (Mary Astor). Far removed from war and safe within their New England home, the “little women” are a closely-knit family and a picture of happiness. When Laurie (Peter Lawford), the grandson of a rich neighbor arrives, the orderly world of the March family is disrupted. The sisters are smitten by this handsome stranger and a story of romance, rivalry, love and loss ensues. As the high spirited and determined Jo, June Allyson gives one of the finest performances of her career, ably supported by the superb ensemble cast. The film is beautifully crafted and deservedly received an Academy Award nomination for its exceptional cinematography. Co-starring Rossano Brazzi as Professor Bhaer.

results.title: Reservoir dogs
results.creator_credit: Quentin Tarantino, Lawrence Bender and Dog Eat Dog Productions
results.brief_description: This exciting and controversial independent feature cemented Tarantino’s reputation as an important filmmaker. A brilliant ensemble cast, including Harvey Keital, Steve Buscemi, Tim Roth and Michael Masden, play a gang of armed robbers involved in a heist that goes comically wrong. Featuring a tight and witty script, this audaciously fast-moving film is influenced by the jubilant cinema of the French New Wave. It is also influenced by a gleefully indulgent love of American pop culture. On its release “Reservoir Dogs” was criticised for its violence, in particular, an unsettling torture scene in which Masden takes sadistic pleasure in murdering a cop. It is the mixing of sadism with a comically amoral detachment that marks the film’s break with the Hollywood tradition of the gangster epic and the film noir. There is no sentimental resolution to “Reservoir Dogs”, no clear-cut good guys and bad guys. An astonishingly assured first feature, that is rivetting, disturbing, funny and sometimes suprisingly homoerotic.
